title: Quiz 1: Historical Evolution & Policy Framework
topicName: Unit One: Introduction to Reproductive Health
description: Assess your understanding of the historical timeline, key policy shifts (ICPD, SMI), and the structure of reproductive health services in Kenya.

questions.question: Which international conference in 1994 marked the global shift from vertical family planning programs to comprehensive, integrated reproductive health services?
questions.explanation: The 1994 International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD) in Cairo endorsed the Reproductive Health Agenda, shifting strategies to meet individual needs through comprehensive care.
questions.hint: This conference took place in Egypt.

questions.question: The concept of providing RH services everyday, during the same visit, under one roof is often referred to as the '___BLANK___ approach'.
questions.explanation: Integrated RH services create a 'supermarket approach' where a client can access multiple services (FP, ANC, etc.) in a single visit, maximizing efficiency.
questions.hint: Think of a large store where you can buy everything at once.

questions.question: Arrange the following events in the evolution of RH programs in Kenya in chronological order (earliest to latest):
questions.explanation: Timeline: FP Programme (1967) -> MCH/FP Integration (1974) -> SMI Launch (1987) -> ICPD Cairo (1994).
questions.hint: Start with the 1960s program focused purely on fertility.

questions.question: Match the level of service delivery with its primary provider or characteristic:
questions.explanation: Community level involves CBDs; Dispensaries are managed by Nurses; Health Centres by Clinical Officers; District services are overseen by the DMOH.
questions.hint: Match the leadership role to the facility type.

questions.question: Which of the following are listed as priority components of the RH Implementation Plan? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Priorities include Safe Motherhood, Family Planning, STI/HIV, Adolescent Health, Gender issues, Cancer screening, Infertility, and Care of the elderly.
questions.hint: Housing is a social issue, not a direct medical RH component.

questions.question: According to the 1994 definition, Reproductive Health is merely the absence of disease or infirmity in the reproductive system.
questions.explanation: RH is defined as a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being in all matters relating to the reproductive system, NOT merely the absence of disease.
questions.hint: Think about the WHO definition of general health.

questions.question: Analyze the text snippet below regarding population trends. What is the primary implication for Reproductive Health services?

richContent.content: 'The population of Kenya was 15.3 million in 1979. By 1998, it had doubled to approximately 30 million. Meanwhile, the growth of the economy has not kept pace with the growth of the population.'

options.text: Services must focus solely on urban areas
Economic growth is irrelevant to health planning
Rapid population growth burdens available health resources, requiring efficient integrated care
Population growth automatically improves health standards

questions.explanation: Rapid population growth without economic growth strains resources (land, facilities), increasing the need for efficient, integrated RH services to manage fertility and health outcomes.
questions.hint: Consider the relationship between resources and population numbers.

questions.question: What is the term for the initiative launched in 1987 to specifically address maternal mortality?
questions.explanation: The Safe Motherhood Initiative (SMI) was launched in Nairobi in 1987 to focus global attention on maternal deaths.

questions.question: Review the table of service levels. Which level is responsible for 'Research testing and introduction of new technologies'?

questions.explanation: The District Level (Secondary) is tasked with research testing and the introduction of new technologies to improve treatment.
questions.hint: Look at the middle row of the table.

questions.question: The 1994 Kenya Health Policy Framework advocated for maintaining vertical, separate programs for efficiency.
questions.explanation: The policy advocated for a shift AWAY from vertical programs towards INTEGRATION to improve efficiency and reduce waste.
questions.hint: Did vertical programs prove efficient or wasteful?
